Award.AwardTitle: Nanoporous Silicon: Probing Dimensionally Constrained Deformation in Non-Metals

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this work is to understand how the mechanical behavior and structural stability of nanoporous silicon are influenced by the combined effects of small deformation volume and large surface-area-to-volume ratio. Silicon, with broad technological importance and wide current application, will serve as a model material for nanostructured non-metallic systems. Recently, a number of research groups have reported that nanoscale silicon structures exhibit ductile deformation below a critical size. Motivated by these results, this project will investigate the mechanical behavior of nanoporous silicon whose ligament structure consists of an interconnected network of fine silicon nanowires. The research approach combines computational and experimental methodologies and leverages an ongoing collaboration between the University of Kentucky and the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology. The proposed research specifically aims to structurally and mechanically characterize nanoporous silicon, and to simulate and model nanoporous silicon deformation. The investigators will utilize a battery of thin film and small-scale test techniques that have been established in Lexington (Kentucky) and Karlsruhe (Germany) as well as atomistic computational models to realize these aims. Combined results will then be leveraged to elucidate the structural stability, mechanical properties and deformation mechanisms of nanoporous silicon, particularly with respect to the role of dimensional constraints placed on silicon deformation by the nanoscale ligament structure.

Success in this research project will benefit efforts to more broadly incorporate nanostructured non-metals in technological applications, as well as the deployment of nanostructured silicon in industrially relevant engineering solutions. The proposed research establishes the fundamental understanding required by related device-level engineering efforts to develop next-generation photovoltaics, optical sensors, battery anodes, flexible electronics or nanoscale light-emitting diodes. In addition, the Kentucky-Karlsruhe collaboration will provide American students with hands-on laboratory experience in a world-class international research environment, German students with an opportunity to live and perform research in the USA, and all students the horizon-broadening opportunity to work with foreign peers in a science-focused cultural exchange.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research grant was to understand the combined effects of small deformation volume and large amounts of surface area on the structure and mechanical behavior of nanoporous silicon (np-Si), as a model for nanostructured non-metallic systems. This project involved material synthesis, mechanical test techniques, in-situ observation of sample behavior during deformation in the electron microscope, and computational modeling of deformation based on experimental characterization of real systems.

 

Nanoporous materials can be produced by a process called “dealloying”, during which a sacrificial element is leached from a precursor alloy and the remaining element(s) reassemble into a porous structure with nanoscale ligaments. Dealloying is typically applied to precursor alloys that require a strong acid to remove the sacrificial element. In this project, magnesium was used as the sacrificial element, and this element could be removed with distilled water. The process utilized here is environmentally benign and can be readily adapted by other groups. In fact, the process of dealloying in the case of np-Si formation is somewhat different from that for nanoporous metals, and seems to involve unique chemical reactions that may warrant subsequent studies.

 

Nanoporous materials exhibit unique and sometimes surprising mechanical behavior. In the case of np-Si, we have observed that ligaments can undergo extensive deformation during in-situ nanoindentation in the TEM, and subsequently recover this deformation completely. The in-situ nanoindentation experiments performed during this project have also indicated that variation of the deformation rate can cause some degree of residual deformation: small indents remain after removal of the indenter, following indentation at higher rates.

 

More comprehensive, ex-situ nanoindentation work revealed that the deformation of np-Si is time-dependent, and that this time-dependence appears to arise from the nanoporous structure itself. This will have broader impact in the field of nanoporous materials and their mechanical behavior, since similar np structures are created by dealloying a wide variety of metals, alloys, and non-metallic materials.

 

In the scope of our computational work on mechanical behavior of np-Au, we modeled the nanoporous structure and its response to various loading conditions. The key finding here was that the load-bearing path, i.e. the portion of the overall nanoporous structure that contributes to stiffness and strength, is much less than one would imagine based on the simple volumetric density of the porous solid. This raises questions about the degree of interconnectivity of ligaments in a nanoporous structure.

 

In terms of technological impact, the optimized processes for fabricating thin film np-Si with various thicknesses could have a direct impact on battery anode fabrication, if this material proves to be effective in that application. The ability to deposit thin films of precursor material that can subsequently be dealloyed using a simple, environmentally friendly process would facilitate the adaptation of np-Si in battery applications.
